title: The Savages
dialogue_triumphs: Jano: 'Do you not realise that all progress is based on exploitation?'
The Doctor: '… This, sir, is protracted murder!'
goofs: If the Elders are such a danger to the Savages, why do they continue to live just outside the city?

continuity_notes.name: The Elders
continuity_notes.description: A group that lives as parasites, draining the 'life energy' from the Outsiders. This process involves extracting both biological elements and psychological qualities.

continuity_notes.name: Life Energy Extraction Process
continuity_notes.description: A method used by the Elders to drain life energy from the Outsiders, transferring both physical and psychological traits.

continuity_notes.name: Jano
continuity_notes.description: An Elder who absorbs the Doctor's life energy and begins to exhibit many of the Doctor's characteristics.

continuity_notes.name: The Doctor
continuity_notes.description: Known as 'the Traveller from Beyond Time' by the Elders, who have watched his progress through Time and Space.

links: The Doctor states: 'I oppose you as I oppose the Daleks or any other menace to common humanity!'

locations.name: Unnamed Planet
locations.description: The planet where the story takes place, possibly a Gallifreyan colony similar to Minyos, Dronid, or the planet of Mawdryn.
locations.current_status: Inhabited by the Elders and the Savages

additional_notes: The story plays intelligent games with witless SF clichés and creates an effective atmosphere. Nobody dies in this story.
bottom_line: 'The Savages' (a story in which nobody dies) plays intelligent games with witless SF clichés. Whilst not aspiring to greatness it does create an effective atmosphere. 'The Face of Evil' of the 60s?
